ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class was a good beginner exposure to the hard skills of environmental science, like conducting a field experiment, analyzing raw data, and writing lab reports from that data. However, my most important takeaway from the class was the joy of identifying trees and being able to (relatively) read the natural landscape around me.
I got to learn a few basic tips and tricks for field experiments and writing scientific lab reports on them.
Practical skills about how to do field research!
Field skills and scientific paper reading. Lab report writing
how to read forests, urban ecology, field and lab techniques etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strengths of the course were the field trips. I learned the most when we were out in the field, typically a forest, and Kealoha or Janey were teaching us about the landscape's history or processes. There was an organic informality, where any of us students could walk about to Kealoha or Janey and ask questions about what we were seeing, or why something is the way it is. I also loved learning to identify trees!! The course felt relaxed and Kealoha and Janey were always super flexible and accommodating. 

The weakness of the class was the in-class component on Tuesdays. Us students were meant to lead discussion, and it typically ended up being pretty low energy and I didn't get much out of the papers. 

The Thursday field trips really made the class.

I thought the course was really fun, especially the field trips. I thought the Tuesday discussions occasionally dragged, but were often about pretty useful/relevant content so I understand why they were included. No real recommendations for how the course can be improved, I thought it was pretty well organized. The iNaturalist project was fun, but I feel like it was difficult writing a useful report from the project. One other thing I would have appreciated is more experience/lessons doing statistical analysis of experiments.

The field trips were definitely the best part of the course. Of course, that's the main point. But I definitely gained actual experience with field science and feel really confident with my abilities moving forward.
Discussion class is very long and hard to keep the ball rolling

strength: prof and TA were super nice and helpful, we had lab/field components every Thursday which was very fun, low workload, lab reports were actually quite fun to write since you actually see patterns from the data you collected and draw knowledge from the readings
weakneas: could have gave us a brief intro in anthropod and tree identification instead of giving us a book to investigate during lab/field sessions

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would say yes. The chance to go outside every week for class was really wonderful, and the iNaturalist project and other lab reports (especially about sugar maples) were super interesting and I got a lot out of them. There were other parts of the class, like the in-class part, which I felt faltered.

It's a great way to get outside and explore New Haven while still feeling productive. The skills I learned didn't feel particularly applicable to my interests, but if you're interested in field work or ecology it's definitely a great class, and generally a great option to fulfill the lab requirement for the EVST B.S. program.

I definitely would, because it's always nice to learn about science by doing science, rather than reading about it. The discussions were often dry and felt pretty redundant after the second week, but the times that we were in the field or in the lab were really fantastic and made up for it.
